title: Monday, 11th April, 2016

PM

While I appreciate the considerable efforts made by the Commission to explore
remedies with the merging parties that seek to eliminate the adverse effects
identified, it is clear that the remedies offered fall well short of what would be
required to meet the relevant legal standard, as detailed in our case submissions.
The proposed remedies are materially deficient as they will not lead to the creation of
a fourth Mobile Network Operator (MNO) capable of competing effectively and in the
long-term with the remaining three MNOs such that it would stem the loss of
competition caused by the merger. In addition, they fail to address concerns arising
from the presence of the merged entity in both the network sharing arrangements,
including the greater risk of coordination that this brings.
The only appropriate remedy that would meet the criteria that the Commission is
bound to apply (ie that the remedies eliminate the competition concerns in their
entirety, are comprehensive, effective and capable of ready implementation) is the
divestment – to an appropriate buyer approved by the Commission – of either the
Three or O2 mobile network businesses, in entirety, or possibly allowing for limited
‘carve-outs’ from the divested business. The divestment would need to include the
mobile network infrastructure and sufficient spectrum to ensure a commercially
viable fourth MNO in the UK. Absent such structural remedies, the only option
available to the Commission is prohibition.

BE

Our Yahoo analysts value the company’s “Core Business” at c.US$6 bn with around half of revenues coming from “Display” services. While it is unclear how much of the business DMGT would take over, we note that with a market cap of c.US$3.65 bn and 1.7x net debt/EBITDA, the company may have to lever up significantly depending on the structure of a deal. In our view, this poses an odd move strategically as the company has been focused on becoming more of a B2B information services company (currently 60% of revs). We believe that the rationale may be around Yahoo’s exposure to the US markets given DMGT’s desire to grow the MailOnline brand in the US.
Implications
We remain Sell rated on DMGT. We value DMGT on a SOTP valuation methodology (unchanged) giving us a 12-month price target of 655p. Risks to our thesis include: (1) stronger-than-expected print advertising (2) faster-than- expected growth in RMS or MailOnline; (3) value-enhancing M&A and (4) favourable FX movements.

BE

Liberum rather more excited by the prospect, being buyers anyway.

11:21 am
BE

DMGT has confirmed that it is in talks with potential Private Equity bidders of Yahoo. This is in line with management's goal of expanding their operations in the US post the success of MailOnline and Elite Daily. Discussions are at an early stage but management have commented in the past that M&A is the priority when it comes to use of cash, and we note that DMGT's buyback programme has ended in December suggesting they have been exploring M&A potential for a number of months.

Unrealised value in current portfolio of assets

We believe that there is a significant amount of unrealised value in DMGT's current portfolio of assets and this value could be realised through a reorganisation of these assets. One potential scenario is that DMGT combine Yahoo's media assets with their own media assets and spin it off whilst taking a significant minority stake in the new business, similar to what they did with Zoopla. This would have a number of benefits, the new media business would be able to offer media buyers a significant amount of high quality inventory. DMGT excluding their media assets would also see a re-rating of the stock as this would leave a higher growth business and it would disassociate the business with the declining newspapers.

Yahoo acquisition to give DMGT greater ability to monetise US traffic

The US has been the main driver of digital growth for DMGT, whilst traffic has grown well they haven't quite monetised this traffic as successfully as they would have liked, traffic is split roughly equally between US, UK and RoW but the majority of revenues still come from the UK. This deal could look to leverage Yahoo's ability to sell advertising in the US and the combined inventory of DMGT/Yahoo would make a compelling offer to media buyers as they could offer them a significant amount of verified impressions (i.e. Human Traffic in a brand safe environment).

The FBI has obtained and validated information regarding a group of malicious cyber actors who have compromised and stolen sensitive information from various government and commercial networks. This group utilized the domains listed herein in furtherance of computer network exploitation (CNE) activities in the United States and abroad since at least 2011. Research and analysis indicate that these domains were associated with the command and control (C2) of customized malicious software. Furthermore, these domains have also been used to host malicious files – often through embedded links in spear phish emails. Any activity related to these domains detected on a network should be considered an indication of a compromise requiring mitigation and contact with law enforcement.

Subject to full implementation of the rationalization plan, the Group has a stronger balance sheet and improved cashflow by virtue of the debt rationalisation exercise

BE

Rents in UK industrial markets are experiencing their strongest growth since
2Q1990, in line with employment in specific sectors. At the same time,
SEGRO has successfully restructured its business and appears well
positioned for growth. We forecast lfl net rent growth, a higher volume of
yield enhancing developments and falling costs of debt driving a
continuous improvement in SEGRO’s ROE (excl. revaluation effects). We
believe increasing evidence of the improved quality of SEGRO’s portfolio
and its lower financial gearing, combined with a positive inflection point in
its macro trends, will lead many investors to apply a lower cost of equity.

11:49 am
PM

Use Preveiw. (oh, youre not on a Mac)

BE

Catalyst
After a return to growth with better than consensus recurring EPS growth in
2015, we forecast 4%, 9% and 13% growth through 2018, putting us further
ahead of company-compiled consensus each year (4%-14%). We are 3%-
12% ahead on EPRA NAV/share, which we expect to benefit from gains on
development as well as positive market trends. We expect these factors
along with growing recognition of the SEGRO’s lower risk profile following
its repositioning and an inflection in UK industrial market rent trends to
support its shares trading on better than historical average multiples.
Valuation
We raise our 12-month EVA-based price target by 10% to 555p, which
implies 33% potential upside vs. 18% for our sector on average. Our price
target implies a 3.9% 12-month forward rolling average earnings yield in 12-
months’ time (vs. its shares trading at 5.3% historically) and a 1% discount
to a 12-month month forward rolling average earnings yield in 12-months’
time (vs. 7% historically). We upgrade SEGRO’s shares to Buy from Neutral.
Key risks
Brexit is a significant potential risk for UK REITs, although we consider
SEGRO’s properties, particularly in continental Europe, to be less at risk.
Weaker industrial occupier demand is a risk to SEGRO letting its
developments.

Symbol opinion vote Comment: Have a check at WP:REFB on how to reference. At present there are links just placed in the text. Don't use the Greybull website if at all possible.
The links must support the facts. Rankersbo (talk) 08:08, 5 November 2014 (UTC)

Contents[show]
Company Structure
Greybull Capital LLP; Registered address; 32 Sloane Street, SW1X 9NR London. A limited liability partnership incorporated April 2010; Registered Nr.OC354497;.[1]

Greybull Capital's 4 members Nathaniel Jerome Meyohas, Marc Meyohas, Richard Cal Perlhagen and Greybull Corporate Partner Ltd;[2] : Greybull Corporate Partner Ltd, is owned 50/50 by Jerome Nathaniel and Marc Meyohas, formed July 2012 [3]

Greybull Capital say they "make long term investments in private companies" with a "broad portfolio spanning investments in the energy, technology, retail, industrial and manufacturing sectors in Europe and the United States".[4]

Greybull Capital is run by brothers Marc and Nathaniel Meyohas and longstanding family friend Richard Perlhagen. “We are a family-owned, family-run business with interests everywhere” Marc Meyohas said in a Sunday Times interview March 2012. Greybull was set up to invest the wealth of the two families, whose ties go back 40 years. The brothers’ father, a French corporate lawyer. Perlhagen’s father sold his Swedish pharmaceuticals empire for tens of millions[5]

Greybull described as secretive financiers and dealmakers. Their Sloane Street office has a blacked-out door with just a buzzer hand-labeled 'Reception' [5]. Greybull's website is 2 sentences on a single page, with an email address.[4]
